Question: CCl4+H2O(drastic conditions)
Comment: SN1 happens only in drastic conditions. Carbene is formed which then reacts with nucleophilic OH-

Question: NF3+H2O->
Comment: Under nondrastic conditions SN1 cant happen. SN2 will need low lying empty orbital for flank attack which is absent.

Question: 2HNO2(g)->
Comment: N2O3 + H2O

Question: 3SiF4+4H2O->
Comment: SiF4 being highly dq+ and empty d orbital readily complexes into d2sp3. This happens only with F-

Question: 4BF3+3H2O->
Comment: BF3 being deficient, readily gets complexated to get an octet. This happens only with F- and OH-

Question: BCl3+NaOH->
Comment: Similar to BF3 complexation, Surplus of OH- in solution will complexate deficient molecule.  Same happens with BeCl2, it is a deficient yet small atom too

Question: NCl3+3H2O->
Comment: N is more EN than Cl and OH attacks Cl, not N

Question: SbCl3+H2O->
Comment: Sb has +3 charge since this is ionic and its solubility is bad because of size of Sb

Question: XeF2+H2O->
Comment: With Xe compounds it is a"Either Go straight to XeO3, ore just become Xe"

Question: XeF4+H2O->
Comment: With Xe compounds it is a"Either Go straight to XeO3, ore just become Xe".

Question: XeF6+H2O->
Comment: With Xe compounds it is a"Either Go straight to XeO3, ore just become Xe"

Question: MH+H2O->
Comment: H- will take H+

Question: TeF6+H2O->
Comment: Hydroxides are more stable in predominantly ionic ones. Only dominantly covalent ones will tautomerize/gemdiol eliminate to get =O groups

Question: SeF6+H2O
Comment: Hydroxides are more stable in predominantly ionic ones. Only dominantly covalent ones will tautomerize/gemdiol eliminate to get =O groups

Question: SF6+H2O
Comment: S is the smallest one showing 6-covalence. This is highly sterically hindered.

Question: P4+H2O->
Comment: Identical treatment is impossible here. Thus it disproportionates unlike regular non-Xe hydrolysis. It can be seen that H3PO4 is not formed but H3PO2 by adding H-OH across rest of the bonds in the other 3 Ps

Question: Depressant Reactions
Comment: Complexing property of Zn is exploited to make ZnS less float-y and settle down
Instructions: Assume impurity in given ore is Zinc based

Question: Cationic Activation Reaction (Froth Floatation)
Comment: CuS is the best floater
Instructions: Assume given ore is Zinc Blende

Question: Anionic Activation Reaction (Froth Floatation)
Comment: CuS is the best floater. Although it is meant for sulphide ores, other ores can also be concentrated by froth floatation when such reactions are possible.

Question: Leaching Bauxite
Comment: Ampho property of Al2O3 and solubility is exploited. Problem with this is that SiO2 which is an acidic oxide, will persist

Question: Leaching Silver
Comment: Complexing property of Ag is exploited to precipitate it

Question: Mond Process
Comment: [Ni(CO)4] is volatile and will also thermally decompose once Seperationerated

Question: Van Arkel Reaction
Comment: MI4 volatile and also decomposes

Question: Test for CN-
Comment: Used in Lasagne's organic tests. First complex is formed by Fe2+, then Fe2+ in solution is oxidized by concentrated H2SO4. Alternative to this is to simply add Fe(II) and Fe(III) seperately instead of letting H2SO4 do the oxidation
Instructions: Use CN instead of CN-. Use typical procedure although several ways are possible. Ignore byproducts for this reaction (way too many of them).

Question: NO2 (characteristic description)
Comment: Appears in group Seperationeration of NO3 and NO2

Question: S2O3-- Group Seperation
Comment: S=S bond is not polar and is not hydrolysed like regular S-X bonds. It wont hydrolyse like usual. SO3-- is formed which further gives SO3-- group Seperation. S8 formed is actually colloidal, not ppt.
Instructions: Ignore any charge in ionic equation

Question: S-- Group Seperation
Comment: Its good to note that H2S is largely covalent and wont give test for S-- in solution generally

Question: CO2 (description)
Comment: SO2 has odour, but same brisk effervescence

Comment: In starch, I3- shows complexation

Question: dil[H+] Anions that dissolve on excess

Question: Ag2S2O3(ppt)+▲->
Comment: Like SO3--, S2SO3-- acts, except the S= gets taken by Ag this time. Same happens other thiosulphate ppts.

Question: Na2S+HNO3->
Comment: Like concentrated HCl and H2SO4, dilute HNO3 can oxidize. S-- becomes S8 with mild oxidizer.

Question: Na2S+HNO3(conc)->
Comment: Conc HNO3 will give NO, Dilute will give NO2. S-- becomes S8 with mild oxidizer.

Question: Anions that give ppt with BaCl2 that dissolve on HCl

Question: CuSO4+KI(excess)->

Question: NO3- Confirmatory
Comment: [H+] creates a condition similar to HNO3 and NO2 is oxidized by HNO3 to NO. NO has an unpaired electron in antibonding and readily donates it to Fe2+ (unlike how Nitroso is formed in diazonium formation). Fe is exceptionally +1 here. This doesnt need concentrated acid unlike NO2-- because these acid must to reduction and it wont disproportionate(not exactly, but qualitatively) like here

Question: Ce+4 (Colour Change)
Comment: Ce(III) is colourless

Question: KNO3+Zn
Comment: This is done in conc. Basic medium to make the reaction to dissolve [Zn(OH)4]--

Question: NH4+ Confirmatory

Question: NaX+Pb(OAc)2->
Comment: Just like AgX, colour becomes yellow with PbI2 (altho not much with Br). Cl is more crystalline.

Question: Cl- Confirmatory
Comment: Chromyl Chloride Test. For some reason Concentrated Acids (in group seperation), Chromates and Manganates don't manage to oxidize Cl- in salt.
Instructions: Use Cl instead of Cl-. Ignore byproducts for this reaction. Add the reagants into reaction in the second step right away (For example like H2O in this reaction: RCHO+KCN->RCH(OH)(CN)+H2O->RCH(OH)COOH)

Question: MnO2 Test for Cl-
Comment: This indirectly oxidizes Cl- in salt. Concentrated acid gives HCl which is then oxidized by the oxidizer.
Instructions: Use Cl instead of Cl-. Ignore byproducts for this reaction.

Question: NaCl+KMnO4 [H+]->
Comment: For some reason Concentrated Acids (in group seperation), Chromates and Manganates don't manage to oxidize Cl- in salt.

Question: Borax Bead test in Oxidizing Flame
Comment: Practically, Oxidizing and Non-luminous are same because atmosphere's got 32% O2 anyways

Question: Borax Bead test in Reducing Flame
Comment: Reduction changes colour

Question: 2HNO2(aq)->
Comment: N2O3 + H2O. NO2 from one HNO2 reduces another HNO2 to HNO3

Question: Washing Soda Bead Test
Comment: While Borax Bead test is majorly answered by lewis acidic oxides with colour giving metals, Sodium Carbonate Bead test is answered by lewis basic oxides (MnO2 and Cr2O3 are amphoteric and MnO oxidized from their stable oxidation state in oxidizing flame to this)

Question: HgCO3+▲->
Comment: Unlike regular decompositions, HgCO3 directly goes to Hg because HgO decomp temperature is pretty low too. Same with nitrates. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: Na2CO3+▲->
Comment: Alkali metal carbonates (ex. Li by diagonal rel) are thermally stable

Question: HNO3+▲->
Comment: Note that same reaction happens in oxidation half. N2O5 (Has an N-O-N bond, it is the anhydride of acid not exactly a nitrogenoxide) wants to become NO2 and NO3 but NO3 is unstable. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: H2SO4+▲(extreme)->
Comment: Note that same reaction happens in oxidation half. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing. When SO4 is the oxidizer it goes to SO2, When SO4 is being *reduced* it goes to S--.

Question: (COOH)2+▲->
Comment: First decarbox at one side, and then how AcOH on dehydration, CO is given. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: NH4IO3+▲->
Comment: If anion is oxidizing, NH3 is oxidized. I2 and Cl2 are not oxidizing per se, so Cl- and I- are not formed unless N2 was reducing in nature. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: NH4NO3+▲->
Comment: Exceptionally N2O is formed instead of N2 because this isnt redox although anion is oxidizing, this is just literally removing H2O to give :kekw:-gas. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: NH4NO2+▲->
Comment: Unlike typical NO2 decomp, this exceptionally goes through NH4NO3 decomposition. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: (NH4)2HPO4+▲->
Comment: All NH4 bonds are replaced with anhydride links, OH unaffected with pure NH3 and H case. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: Na(NH4)HPO4+▲->
Comment: All NH4 bonds are replaced with anhydride links, OH are also touched when theres a better metal around. Metal bonds are unaffected and H-P are also unaffected. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: NaNO3+▲->
Comment: Unlike regular NO2-, Group I nitrites are stable similar to same stabilization that stabilizes peroxides and superoxides. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: AuCl3+▲(mild)->
Comment: Heating halides supports leaving of X2 even if bigger ox state is more stable if difference in stability is small enough. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing

Question: MCl2.2H2O+▲->
Comment: Hydrated chloride salts at actually complexes and Cl leaves easier than O in H2O->M

Question: KOAc+▲->
Comment: Group I carbonates are stable and won't break further. Decarbox does not happen as there is not driving force here unlike beta carbonyl in oxalate. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: H2SO3+▲(extreme)->
Comment: Acids not at their ortho ox state or mineral form disproportionate simply because the extremes are more stable than others. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing which is S8 here. Mild heating gives H2O+SO2, on extreme heating SO2 reacts further with H2SO3.

Question: HOCl+▲->
Comment: Acids not at their ortho ox state or mineral form disproportionate simply because the extremes are more stable than others.

Question: HClO3+▲->
Comment: Cl2O5+H2O. This is already at ortho ox state, this reaction is more similar to HNO2-> N2O5. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: H3PO2+▲->
Comment: Acids not at their ortho ox state or mineral form disproportionate simply because the extremes are more stable than others. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.

Question: Ag2C2O4+▲->
Comment: Although AgO+CO+CO2 is expected like in AgCO3, AgO + CO -> Ag + CO2. Generally, Pyrolysis are driven by ppt-ing or gas-ing.
